Award.AwardTitle: Increasing the Quality and Quantity of Mathematics Teachers for High-Need Districts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The major goals of the Millersville University (MU) Noyce Scholars Program include increasing the number of highly qualified secondary mathematics teachers and providing the teachers to the high-need school districts in the region. Over the life of the grant, the Scholars Program provides 30 scholarships for mathematics teacher candidates in the final two years of their preparation. Approximately 70% of the scholarship recipients are traditional undergraduates, while 30% are being awarded to non-traditional, career-changing, Post-Baccalaureate Certification candidates. The project is a collaborative effort among faculty from the university's School of Science and Mathematics and School of Education, and it includes a team of investigators who are all senior personnel, with broad experience, representing mathematics, mathematics education and teacher preparation programs.

This project addresses the gap between the number of teachers annually certified at MU and those who are pursuing teaching careers in high-need school districts. The project is building on the previous success of the "urban summer seminar in Philadelphia", and the "university's urban field placements in Lancaster, Lebanon, and York School Districts of Pennsylvania" projects. Beyond increasing the number of highly qualified mathematics teachers who go on to teach in high-need districts, the project also enhances existing teacher training networks and strengthens existing partnerships with high-need school districts. Candidates are experiencing at least four distinct urban education experiences during early field placements, an urban one-week immersion summer seminar, and student teaching. Additionally, by participating in recruitment seminars and regular colloquium talks, all MU STEM majors have opportunities to hear guest speakers, including Noyce program alumni, discuss their experiences in teaching in high-need school districts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Noyce Program at Millersville University has provided mathematics education majors with a greater opportunity to develop skills necessary to teach in high-need schools.

One of the biggest impacts from the project, was the successful training of twenty-five Noyce Scholars of mathematics – all of whom are currently employed for the 2018-2019 year in twenty-four different schools, in nineteen districts and seven states, and all 25 of them are contracted in high-need districts either in fulfillment of their commitment or following completion of their obligated service. This is a significant increase in the number of our program's graduates specifically prepared to teach in high-needs districts prior to the start of the grant (0). The Millersville University mathematics education faculty established stronger working relationships with several local districts high-need districts (School District of Lancaster, Harrisburg City School District, Lebanon School District and Reading School District). These local districts have collectively hired eight Noyce scholars in the past five years, and have all been considered for future collaboration in potential outreach projects and field placements.

The PI team expanded in the past year to examine how the program might move forward with more grant support, expanded school-district connections, and greater ways to impact the university community as a whole. The discussions and plans that occurred as a result will lead the team to explore ways in which they and their future students can impact the local school districts. They will also be using the lessons learned from the project to strengthen recruiting and professional development opportunities for all future secondary mathematics teachers at Millersville as well as beyond.

The project has fundamentally changed the preparation of mathematics teachers by directly impacting our mathematics education faculty's experiences in high-need districts. Having developed stronger partnerships with several local high-need districts, many of the lessons learned by our Noyce scholars can be extended to all future teacher candidates.
